channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Confusion and Frustration Reign as Elon Musk Cuts Half of Twitter’s Staff
item.description: The layoffs hit across many divisions, including the engineering and machine learning units, the teams that manage content moderation, and the sales and advertising departments.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Ryan Mac and Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Friday morning, at least nine security guards were seen patrolling Twitter headquarters in San Francisco. Employees had been told to stay home as layoffs were carried out.

item.title: Twitter’s Advertisers Pull Back as Layoffs Sweep Through Company
item.description: Elon Musk, Twitter’s new owner, acknowledged that ad spending on the platform had slumped. He blamed the drop on pressure from activists.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu
item.media:description: More companies have paused their spending on Twitter out of concern that their ads could appear alongside problematic content.

item.title: On Social Media, Hunting for Voter Fraud Becomes a Game
item.description: Players who post about irregularities are awarded points or titles, leading participants to question the legitimacy of elections.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel
item.media:description: A woman monitored a ballot drop box in a parking lot in Mesa, Ariz., on Oct. 24. Hunting for voter fraud has become a game on social media.

item.title: Worries Grow That TikTok Is New Home for Manipulated Video and Photos
item.description: Misleading edits, fake news stories and deepfake images of politicians are starting to warp reality on the popular video platform.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu
item.media:description: Manipulated media is spreading before the midterms on TikTok, whose policies prohibit digital forgeries “that mislead users by distorting the truth.”

item.title: YouTube May Have Misinformation Blind Spots, Researchers Say
item.description: The video platform said it had limited the spread of misinformation ahead of Election Day, but new research showed that false narratives continued to slip through.
item.dc:creator: Nico Grant
item.media:description: The nonprofit Media Matters identified a variety of videos on YouTube that contained misinformation.

item.title: Fed Up With Political Text Messages? Read On.
item.description: In this polarized climate, hundreds of Americans told us they agree on one thing: Campaigns must stop spamming voters’ phones with unwanted political texts.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer

item.title: On Twitter, Who Needs a Check Mark When You Can Have a Rat?
item.description: Elon Musk wants Twitter users to pay to be verified. An artist offers a wry alternative.
item.dc:creator: Madison Malone Kircher

item.title: Is This A.I. Thanksgiving Menu Better Than a Human’s?
item.description: Researchers are using artificial intelligence to create recipes, complete with appetizing photos and back stories. But Thanksgiving poses a challenge.
item.dc:creator: Priya Krishna and Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Timothy O'Connell for The New York Times
item.media:description: Can artificial intelligence create a better Thanksgiving menu than people can? A reporter, Priya Krishna, put that to the test.

item.title: Meet the Woman Planning an Underwater Highline
item.description: Part public housing for fish, part carbon-capture project, part art installation, Ximena Caminos’s project for Miami Beach, known as the ReefLine, aims to call attention to the challenges facing the city’s marine life.
item.dc:creator: Nora Walsh
item.media:credit: Eva Marie Uzcategui for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ximena Caminos, who is developing the ReefLine In Miami Beach, is an art curator, cultural placemaker and founder of the ocean-centric nonprofit BlueLab Preservation Society.

item.title: Twitter Employees on Life Under Elon Musk
item.description: A radical shake-up is underway at the social media company.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Paula Szuchman, Corey Schreppel, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Elisheba Ittoop
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration: The New York Times; Photo: Cayce Clifford for The New York Times

item.title: Elon Musk Begins Layoffs at Twitter As Some Employees File Lawsuit
item.description: The social media company’s 7,500 employees have been bracing for job cuts since Mr. Musk took it over last week.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and Ryan Mac
item.media:description: Twitter’s headquarters in San Francisco. About half the company’s 7,500 workers appeared set to lose their jobs.

item.title: Elon Musk, Under Financial Pressure, Pushes to Make Money From Twitter
item.description: The billionaire and his advisers have discussed adding paid direct messages, fees to watch videos and other features to the service.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Ryan Mac
item.media:description: Twitter’s headquarters in San Francisco. Last year, the company had less money in cash flow than what it now owes its lenders annually.

item.title: Amazon, Lyft and Other Tech Companies Announce Job Cuts and Hiring Freezes
item.description: Amazon said it was pausing corporate hiring, while Lyft and Stripe said they were cutting jobs.
item.dc:creator: Kalley Huang
item.media:description: Lyft said on Thursday that it would cut 13 percent of its employees.

item.title: Elon Musk Takes a Page Out of Mark Zuckerberg’s Social Media Playbook
item.description: As Mr. Musk takes over Twitter, he is emulating some of the actions of Mr. Zuckerberg, who leads Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Ryan Mac and Tiffany Hsu
item.category: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People
item.media:description: Elon Musk in January 2020. As Twitter’s new owner, he met this week with civil rights groups.

item.title: Tumblr Reverses Nudity Ban
item.description: Reversing a 2018 ban, the company said that nudity and “mature subject matter” would be allowed. But “visual depictions of sexually explicit acts” remain off limits.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy
item.media:credit: Thiago Prudencio/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images
item.media:description: The blogging site Tumblr lost about a third of its traffic after it announced in 2018 that it was banning explicit posts.

item.title: Campaigns Skirt Political Ad Rules by Paying Influencers
item.description: Campaigns are using social media influencers as a way to reach young and diverse voters, a novel and mostly unregulated strategy. Some are even spreading the message through dating apps.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai
item.media:credit: Logan R. Cyrus for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ky’Wuan Dukes, a Johnson C. Smith University student, has worked with a Democratic political action committee to reach young voters with posts on his Instagram account.

item.title: What Is Twitter Verification? A History.
item.description: Elon Musk, who recently closed a deal to acquire the social media company, could soon charge a monthly fee for the blue verification badge that indicates a Twitter account is authentic.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Elon Musk is considering charging $8 to $20 a month to verify Twitter accounts.

item.title: Personal Tech Has Changed. So Must Our Coverage of It.
item.description: Our tech problems have become more complex, so we are rebooting the Tech Fix column to focus on the societal implications of the tech we use.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen
item.media:credit: Christie Hemm Klok for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brian X. Chen has written The Times’s Tech Fix column since 2015.

item.title: Debunking Voting Misinformation About the Midterm Elections
item.description: Here are some of the main falsehoods and rumors that have spread on social media in the lead-up to Election Day.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting misinformation and rumors have been building on social media, including about ballot drop boxes and mail-in voting.

item.title: Bill Outlawing Online Suicide Assistance Would Open Sites to Liability
item.description: Bipartisan legislation in the House targets not only the online activity of individual users but also the website operators hosting it.
item.dc:creator: Gabriel J.X. Dance and Megan Twohey
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matthew van Antwerpen with his mother, Sharon Luft. He died by suicide shortly after joining a website where other members gave him advice and detailed instructions.

item.title: Security Cameras Make Us Feel Safe, but Are They Worth the Invasion?
item.description: Internet cameras like Amazon’s Ring come at a high cost to our privacy.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen

item.title: The Story Behind the Roku Screen Saver
item.description: Instead of streaming a new TV show or movie, some Roku users are in it for the screen saver.
item.dc:creator: Luke Winkie

item.title: People Love to Hate-Watch Tech Villains. That Won’t Hurt Spotify.
item.description: “The Playlist” resembles other TV dramas that follow founders to their eventual comeuppance — except Spotify isn’t facing any messy implosion.
item.dc:creator: Peter C. Baker

item.title: Elon Musk’s Twitter Faces Exodus of Advertisers and Executives
item.description: At least five Twitter executives have left in recent days, as one of the world’s largest ad companies said clients should pause spending on the social media platform.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Tiffany Hsu and Ryan Mac
item.media:description: Elon Musk closed a $44 billion deal for Twitter last week and is shaking up the social media company.

item.title: Security Training Group Asks Elon Musk to Rid Twitter of Antisemitism
item.description: An organization that helps secure Jewish facilities across North America said Twitter had an “antisemitism problem,” and asked its new owner to fix it.
item.dc:creator: Nico Grant
item.media:description: A nonprofit security group is calling on Elon Musk to tackle antisemitism on Twitter.

item.title: Uber’s Revenue Is Up 72 Percent From Last Year, but It Posts a Loss
item.description: The company had strong revenue growth but lost money in part because of its investments in other ride-hailing businesses.
item.dc:creator: Kalley Huang
item.media:description: “Even as the macroeconomic environment remains uncertain, Uber’s core business is stronger than ever,” Dara Khosrowshahi, Uber’s chief executive, said in a statement.

item.title: Truth Social’s Influence Grows Despite Its Business Problems
item.description: The right-wing social network faces two federal investigations and an uncertain financial future. But it has still managed to outpace its rivals.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson and Matthew Goldstein
item.media:description: Truth Social had 1.7 million unique visitors in September, according to Similar Web, which monitors web traffic.

item.title: Republicans Continue to Spread Baseless Claims About Pelosi Attack
item.description: Some of the conspiracy theories have already seeped into the Republican mainstream.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:description: Paul Pelosi, the husband of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, was attacked in the couple’s San Francisco home on Friday by an intruder asking, “Where is Nancy?”

item.title: Elon Musk, Plus a Circle of Confidants, Tightens Control Over Twitter
item.description: The billionaire and a group of his friends and advisers are working on layoff plans and how to swiftly change Twitter’s product, said people with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac, Ryan Mac and Kate Conger
item.media:description: Elon Musk, the new owner of Twitter, has flown to New York after spending much of last week at the social media company’s San Francisco headquarters.

item.title: Midterm Disinformation Has Taken Over Pennsylvania
item.description: One state’s experience underscores how pervasive false and misleading information has become in the country’s electoral process, online and off.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: A post on Twitter falsely claimed that Sen. Doug Mastriano, a Republican candidate for governor of Pennsylvania, said that Iran’s supreme leader had “the right idea of how women should be treated.”

item.title: FTC Accuses Chegg Homework Help App of ‘Careless’ Data Security
item.description: Chegg, a homework help app, exposed the data of 40 million users, including details about some students’ sexual orientation and religion, regulators said in a legal complaint.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer

item.title: Instagram Users Report Widespread Account Suspensions
item.description: Some users said they could not access the social media app and had been notified that their accounts were suspended. The company behind the app said Monday evening that the issue had been resolved.
item.dc:creator: April Rubin and Kalley Huang
item.media:description: Many Instagram users woke up Monday to a notification that their accounts had been suspended.

item.title: Can Elon Musk Make the Math Work on Owning Twitter? It’s Dicey.
item.description: Mr. Musk faces financial challenges in owning Twitter. The site frequently loses money and took on $13 billion in debt for the blockbuster deal.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:description: Twitter’s headquarters in San Francisco. Elon Musk’s ability to make the numbers work will have a direct impact on the social media company’s health.

item.title: Elon Musk Is Said to Have Ordered Job Cuts Across Twitter
item.description: The billionaire planned to begin layoffs as soon as Saturday, people with knowledge of the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Ryan Mac, Sheera Frenkel and Mike Isaac
item.media:description: Twitter’s headquarters in San Francisco. Layoffs had been expected and feared by Twitter employees.
